newsitem.title: HONG KONG: ASIAN DEBT MARKETS - KEB steps up with sub FRN.
newsitem.headline: ASIAN DEBT MARKETS - KEB steps up with sub FRN.

text.p: Asian debt markets were slow on Tuesday after a long holiday weekend in Hong Kong, with a subordinated bond for Korea Exchange Bank the major issue.
But there are some interesting deals in prospect.
Korea Exchange Bank offered some excitement with a US$200 million callable, subordinated step-up bond launched via joint bookrunners Chase Manhattan Asia and Merrill Lynch Far East.
The 10-year subordinated notes were launched at par and re-offered at 99.95. They can be called after five years.
The notes pay a quarterly coupon of 64 basis points over the three-month London Interbank Offered Rate for years one through five and LIBOR plus 200 basis points thereafter.
The re-offer yield is LIBOR plus 65 basis points payable quarterly for years one through five and LIBOR plus 132.5 basis points for years one through 10.
The syndicate group was small, with only six other banks joining the bookrunners, and the leads kept a large share of the issue on the view that it would trade in the secondary market, bankers said.
"Subordinated issues are the ones in Asia that are most likely to be syndicated like true Eurobonds," remarked one syndicate manager.
That's because investors in subordinated debt tend to look at it as a trading instrument rather than as something to hold on their books, he said.
KEB International participated in the deal as co-lead manager. ABN AMRO Securities (Far East), ANZ, PaineWebber International, SBC Warburg and Tokyo-Mitsubishi International were co-managers.
Syndicate managers in London today said Korea Development Bank is expected to launch a US$500 million bond by the end of November, probably a global with a tenor of five to 10 years.
From the Philippines, Palawan's governor announced that the province will issue US$100 million worth of bonds to finance infrastructure and development projects.

The province's share of revenues from Shell Philippines Exploration, operator of the Camago-Malampaya field, the country's biggest gas find, will be used to guarantee the bond, Palawan governor Salvador Socrates said.

In the nearer-term, Merrill Lynch is expected to launch a perpetual subordinated bond guaranteed by Hong Kong's Swire Pacific this week. The deal is thought to be the first perpetual issue for an Asian borrower.
Blue-chip Swire is a rare issuer and bankers expect the bond to attract interest for that reason.
